text: setti is the search for exterrestrial
intelligence and IT addresses the
question are we alone in the universe
this is a question which has goes back
to the dawn of History uh but for most
of human history it's been in the
province of religion and philosophy 50
years ago however it became part of
Science and the trailblazing work of a
young astronomer named Frank Drake uh
set the trend uh Frank decided to start
scanning the skies with a large radio
telescope in the hope of stumbling
across a a message from ET seemed a
somewhat quixotic Enterprise when he
began but over the years it's grown and
grown it's now an international effort
and I think it's taken seriously by many
scientists and so it really consists of
using radio telescopes choosing Target
Stars where it's conceivable there might
be some sort of advanced St in
civilization uh and hoping that they
might be beaming radio messages our way
uh and so the at the 50th anniversary of
this it seems to me a good time to take
stock uh because after all we've had uh
nothing but an eerie silence in 50 years
so these astronomers have been patiently
pursuing this Quest I might say Frank
Drake himself is still in the game 50
years on this is heroism of an unusual
sort who else do you know who's devised
the scientific experiment
and has pursued it for 50 years got a
null result and is still smiling and
optimistic so uh Frank Drake is a Great
Hero Of Mine uh and I admire his Zeal
and positivism uh but it is just an
eerie silence and so the question is are
we doing the wrong thing should we be
looking somewhere else or in some other
way should we broaden The Surge and my
conclusion is really that uh I think
what the CTI people are doing is just
great and I hope they go on doing it and

start thinking outside the proverbial

in which we could try to track down
ET if you ask the astronomers at the
sharp end of seti why they think there
has been an eerie silence they'll say
well we only have been doing it for 50
years we've just started what more do
you expect it's a a big universe out
there and in fact to put that into
context they looked carefully at just a
few stars there are 400 billion stars
within our Milky Way galaxy alone so it
is a needle and a Hast stack searge of
course it's easy to conclude simply that
they just haven't been doing it long
enough or hard enough uh it's no
surprise they haven't heard anything but
the alternative is uh that we are indeed
alone in the universe and it's
impossible to answer that question uh
because there are so many unknown
factors if we're looking for
intelligence in the the Universe I think
everybody assumes that this has to start
with life and so the question is How
likely is it that there'll be life
elsewhere in the universe now when I was
a student almost nobody thought there
was any life beyond Earth today it's
fashionable to say that uh there's life
all over the place the universe is
teeming with it but the scientific facts
on the ground haven't really changed
we're still just as ignorant as we were
40 or 50 years ago about how life began
got a very good theory of the evolution
of Life once to get started but it's how
did it get going in the first place uh
we we don't need a blowby blow account
of exactly how it got going on Earth uh
but we would at least like to know
whether it was a very probable event or
a very improbable event and in our
present state of ignorance we can't even
pin that down we can't even bracket the
odds uh it could have been a
stupendously improbable fluke a freak
chemical accident that occurs just once
in the universe or it could be that life
emerges automatically and naturally as
part of the underlying scheme of things
maybe the universe has intrinsically
biofriendly laws uh that brings life
into being all over the place we don't
know it's only fashion that has said the
pendulum has swung from extreme
skepticism about extraterrestrial life
to extreme extreme credulity the truth
is somewhere in between uh but uh to pin
it down we've really got to address that
question How likely is it that life will
arise on an earthlike Planet I should
say we know that there are many many
other Earths out there we're almost
certain that there would be upwards of a
billion earthlike planets in our galaxy
alone so there's no lack of real estate
where life might happen uh but what we
don't know is How likely it is given the

Planet like Earth How likely is it that
life will pop up and inhabit it we don't
know the answer to that
